messageBody:
OK.
I'm sure, too, that the mediator knows nothing (and must not know anything)
about the specific GUI underlying implementation and behavior.
I was only trying to make an example to tell the fact that every single form
of a multi-form GUI driven application can sometimes be considered as an
application itself.
The only problem is that a single form could have its behavior driven by
some data lying inside the depth of the application itself.
So from one side seems already hard to prepare the fixture (in the depth of
the application) but moreover, from the other side, seems to me even harder
to test even a simple behavior of a form.

The main fact stil remains: do you all have successfully used JUnit in order
to make GUI testing?
If yes at which level have you ever did it (with JUnit)? Would you share
some successful strategy by which you accomplished in doing that?

Thank you,

Or try this (a real-world case):

I'm editing a field in my form, and something happens asynchronously
such that the action of editing a field in the form is no longer valid.
There are several options of what to do at the interface level (with
varying degrees of UI acceptableness and programmatic complexity), but
your mediator knows nothing of the editor, nor of how it relates to the
form, or of any other transient objects that may be introduced (dialogs,
swapped-out panes) in order to rectify the situation.

The programmatic easy-to-test solution may not be the one required for
usability of the UI.
